title: How to Re Fuse a Power Supply

steps.title: Switch off the socket that is connected to the power supply.
steps.content: Switch off the socket that is connected to the power supply. Unplug the line voltage power cord from the socket. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Use a screwdriver to remove the screws of the PSU .
steps.content: Use a screwdriver to remove the screws of the PSU . Remove the PSU casing. Unplug the low voltage cables that are connected to the drives and motherboard. Remove any cards that may obstruct your view of the power supply. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Generally, the power supply is held in place by 4 torx screws.
steps.content: Generally, the power supply is held in place by 4 torx screws. Unscrew them using the torx screwdriver and remove the power supply from the PSU. [3] X Research source

steps.title: The warranty is a stamped sticker that is on one of the edges of the power supply.
steps.content: The warranty is a stamped sticker that is on one of the edges of the power supply. It consists of the warranty date, a bar code and a ‘pass’ stamp. If the warranty has expired, cut across the sticker safety seal and open the power supply case. [4] X Research source

steps.title: The fuse is usually located on one corner of the power supply.
steps.content: The fuse is usually located on one corner of the power supply. Use an ohm meter to check the fuse. If the ohm meter is showing readings below 0.1 ohms, or if there is resistance on the meter, then you will know that the fuse has blown. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Plug in the soldering iron and heat it to about 700 degrees.
steps.content: Plug in the soldering iron and heat it to about 700 degrees. Touch the tip of the soldering iron to the tin wires on either side of the fuse. As the solder softens, gently push the fuse away from the circuit board. Once the soldering is complete, you can remove the fuse. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Buff each end of the fuse with emery paper to dull the plating.
steps.content: Buff each end of the fuse with emery paper to dull the plating. Take the six inch long stripped 24 gauge wire with flux and tin it with resin solder. Tin the ends of the fuse, after which you can solder the wires to the ends. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Use the wire cutter to remove any excess pins from the board.
steps.content: Use the wire cutter to remove any excess pins from the board. Also, cut the gauge wire with only an inch of space from the fuse joint. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Place the new fuse onto the circuit board and solder it into place with the soldering iron.
steps.content: Place the new fuse onto the circuit board and solder it into place with the soldering iron. Once this has been completed, use the ohmmeter to test the fuse.

steps.title: Once the fuse is showing good readings on the ohmmeter, close the power supply case.
steps.content: Once the fuse is showing good readings on the ohmmeter, close the power supply case. Keep it back into the PSU and screw it in. Replace the PSU casing and plug it in for use.
